text: hi everyone nicetonydaytano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review
of the new caroline polo check record
pang this is an album i've been tracking
ever since the release of caroline's
single
door which was dropped this past june
and
every song she has teased us with in the
lead up to this record has been good
or great what sounds like a futuristic
and progressive take on artpop
pang was shaping up to be one of the
more promising albums of the year and
while it was unfortunate to see the
demise of caroline's former band
chairlift in 2017 i would like to hear
her move on to greener pastures with a
solo effort
and that's exactly what pang is and
does it's pretty hard to deny just how
sweet cleanly produced and fantastical
many
songs on this record are it's like i'm
listening to bits of charlie xcx
meets alternative r b meets k bush
meets maybe some top 40 music in 2019
and that direction shouldn't be too
surprising considering some of the
people
producing this thing people like andrew
wyatt of mike snow
as well as a.g cook and danielle harl of
the pc music camp together
they handle the bulk of the production
on this record the future of pop is here
and it's pc so i was pretty psyched to
try this thing however i was a little
scared by
the initial moments of the record which
i don't think are
all that great not at the quality level
of singing and songwriting i was
expecting given the singles
the intro cut the gate is very smooth
but it's about as fulfilling as
an exchange with a walmart greeter it's
short and by the time it's over i
realized i've got nothing out of it and
after this a few bland cuts like the
title track
i like the angular synths that play
throughout many passages of this song
but
the tone and the energy of this track is
just way
too subdued for the start of an album
this is more like a
cool down moment on the back end of a
full-length record not to mention the
song features one of caroline's most
underwhelming vocal performances too and
the song new normal
the beat on this instrumental just
sounds like a cheap attempt at working
some
foreign flavors and rhythms into the
record that didn't really need to be
there especially since they
they kind of clash with these strange
country fried guitars that
pop in here and there just sliding in
with a touch of distortion
i think the record continues to get
better from here though
the song hit me where it hurts is a
really effective attempt at working some
glamorous r
b into the project caroline and wyatt
put their own
weirdly minimal spin on it i love these
soaring vocals and rich chords on the
hook
i like how disjointed and sparse the
beat is behind the verses
there are also hits of background vocals
at some points on the track too that
almost
feel like ad-libs it's really like i'm
listening to deconstructed
r b the song i give up features more
solid tune writing as well as very
fractured sparse rhythms
the vocals on this one are raw very
naked but so
angelic and how bare the verses are just
makes the
choruses feel even more euphoric with
that rush of background vocals
and bass when it finally hits now look
all of this is good so far
we have some momentum going in the track
list caroline's vocals are sounding
great
well executed expressive mature but
something you should anticipate with
this record is that
the whole thing is very very very low
key
very moody too this is not a snappy pop
record
which is something some people might
have assumed going into this project
given some
singles like so hot you're hurting my
feelings the vibe of the track is pretty
smooth but it's honestly the most high
octane moment on the entire record so if
the shiny synth chords and lightly
distorted guitars in the background of
this one
are not enough um for you you might not
dig on this one i don't really see the
lack of fireworks on this record as
entirely a bad thing though
especially given how gorgeous and
enchanting nearly every song here is
you have the dreamy and acoustic look at
me now the vocals really sell this one
it's so elegant and elements of it
remind me of breezier
janglier more euphoric cuts from the
cocktail twins discography
meanwhile the dark subterranean base on
insomnia paired with the
bright futuristic synth tones and vocal
harmonies feels like
taking pc music aesthetics and applying
it to
like an ambient pop blueprint the song
ocean of tears was a great single in the
lead up to this record i
still love hearing it in the midst of
this record and the more that i listen
to it i swear to god
there are elements of this track
aesthetically that kind of remind me
of travis scott's 90210 off of rodeo
it's the atmosphere it's the small hits
of auto-tuned ad-libs in the background
it's the singing that sometimes reminds
me of casey hills
it's also the punchy beat while again i
do think there are some aesthetic
similarities the
tune is vastly different very heady but
very catchy which is part of the course
for most of the tracks on this record
while this is certainly a pop album it's
structured like a pop album it is hooky
like a pop album
there's something about the mood the
tone the vibe of the whole thing that
just
comes off very cerebral the beautiful
songs in the tracklist keep
rolling with hey big eyes also go as a
dream although i don't know how much i
care for the intro
on this track which in pure pc music
fashion
is auto-tuned sounds alien almost as if
a cyborg or an ai
is singing the song and i think that's
something that works with most artists
who work with danny work with cook
work with even sophie and are deeply
embracing all these futurist sounds and
visuals
but for the most part it makes this
track stick out like a sore thumb
not in a great way because a lot of the
songs up until this point
feel pretty organic at least vocally one
thing i do want to point out
is some of the background vocals on the
song the ha ha ha
ha ha ha ha which i see as a very
conscious
laurie anderson shout out appreciate
that i think the song caroline shut up
sticks out for much better reasons
though
there's quite a bit of swagger on this
track vocally
even though the song is about expressing
doubt in
the realm of love and wanting to quell
that so caroline sings to herself when
she's filling her head with these ideas
shut up the track is in 3 4 and i think
it does a great job of taking the
stereotypical blueprint of an old-school
spacious waltzy type of ballad with lots
of drama
and applying some modern synthetic
elements to it the song's door and
parachute make sure the entire album
ends off on a really strong note
back in the city i'm just another
girl in a sweater and yeah pang is just
another great forward-thinking quality
produced
and super catchy thoughtful pop record
granted it's not the most innovative or
consistent
record in this style that i've heard
this year and i think the track list
mostly runs like a bunch of disjointed
ideas not really any overall themes or
concepts on this thing at least to my
ears though a lot of the tracks do seem
to center around love
personal connections and emotions and as
i mentioned earlier i think the album's
initial moments are
not quite as strong as the album's final
moments
but a vast majority of these tracks
these 14 tracks
are um are pure fire and i can only hope
that caroline's efforts from here
grow more ambitious thematic as well as
focused although i can't say i'm
complaining too much right now because
as
is this is really great feeling a light
too decent eight on this one
tran position have you given this album
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next
hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well
over here next to my head is another
video that you can check out hit that up
or the link to subscribe to the channel
anthony fantano caroline policek
forever
